awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Testing predictions of the core-satellite and resource-breadth hypotheses in small mammal communities: field tests of a macroecological pattern
awd_abstract_narration:
Have you ever wondered why some animals (like squirrels, raccoons, and crows) are common and seem to be found everywhere, while others are rare and occur only in a few places? Ecologists have asked this question too, and they have been working on this puzzle for over a century. The answer could depend on the variety of foods that animals can eat, the ability of animals to move long distances, or both. On the one hand, animals that can thrive on a range of different foods, what ecologists sometimes call generalists, should be common and widespread, while picky eaters should be rare and found only in a few places. On the other hand, animals that can quickly move into areas from which they have disappeared should also be common and widespread, while animals that stay put should be rare and found in only a few places. Like many answers in ecology, it's probably some of both. The researchers on this project are working to discover how diet and movement ability shape where animals live and how many individuals live in a particular area. Results of this research project could be useful in understanding why some species (like endangered species) are rare and slow to recover following legal protections, while other species (like native pests or invasive species) are common, even in the face of human development. Through this project, the researchers will train two graduate students, a project manager, and four research assistants, and will use the existing infrastructure of a long-term experiment around which to center undergraduate field courses at their respective institutions. 

Positive correlations between a species' abundance and its range size are among the most general patterns in ecology. Two particularly compelling hypotheses, Hanski's Core-Satellite hypothesis and Brown's Resource-Breadth hypothesis, have been proposed to explain this pattern. The Core-Satellite hypothesis posits that differential rates of movement underlie abundance-distribution relationships, such that widespread species are buffered against local extinction by dispersal from the surrounding region. In contrast, the Resource-Breath hypothesis invokes differences in the ability of species to exploit a range of resources: abundant, widespread species should be ecological generalists capable of exploiting a wider variety of resources than rare, geographically restricted species (i.e., ecological specialists). For all of their intuitive appeal, however, support for the central, contrasting predictions of each hypothesis, that new individuals at a locality should arise mostly from dispersal (Core-Satellite hypothesis) versus in situ reproduction (Resource-Breadth hypothesis), has been scant. The researchers will integrate consumer-resource interactions with estimates of dispersal and in situ recruitment in a guild of herbivorous small mammals (rodents, shrews, elephant shrews). Two manipulations, the erection of dispersal barriers and a resource removal, will be established within a pre-existing, long-term experiment. Under this award, the researchers will determine whether abundant, widespread species maintain their extensive distributions through higher rates of dispersal, in situ recruitment, or both.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ecological communities are widely known to be composed of a few common, widespread species that occur together with many rare and geographically restricted ones. One prominent idea about how to explain this pattern suggests that the common, widespread species are “ecological generalists”, capable of thriving in a wide range of habitats or on a wide range of foods. Meanwhile, the rarer and more ecologically restricted species are thought to require more specialized diets and thus they are limited in where they can find the right foods to eat. The major goal of this project was to help understanding why some species are common and others are rare, which can offer valuable information for species conservation and environmental management.

As part of a long-term experiment in central Kenya, our team of international researchers tested the idea that food availability determines which species may be common or rare in a diverse community of small mammals, including fringe-tailed gerbils, pouched mice, rufous elephant shrews, and others. We tracked how individual animals within the populations selected food and compared how closely that selection matched food that was available in their area. The team live-trapped small mammals six times per year in a network of experimental plots called ‘UHURU’ (which stands for: Ungulate Herbivory Under Rainfall Uncertainty). This experiment excludes or allows large mammalian herbivores (e.g., elephant, giraffe, zebra) into 18 1-ha plots in at the Mpala Research Centre in Kenya. A key feature of UHURU is that the combination of large-mammal exclusion and rainfall variability causes marked differences in plant-community structure and composition—and thus food availability for small mammals—among the 18 replicate plots. Using high-throughput genomic techniques called ‘DNA metabarcoding’ to investigate the diets of small mammals that we captured, we learned that the abundant and widespread small mammals consumed a greater diversity of the foods available in their environment compared to the rare and restricted ones. This result supported the ‘resource breadth hypothesis’ that the common species tend to be the generalists while the rarer species tend to be the specialists.

Thus far, the project has contributed to 13 peer-reviewed scientific publications and 2 PhD theses that either directly addressed the question of commonness vs. rarity or more generally contributed to the development of laboratory and computational resources that are needed to apply genomic technologies to ecological questions. Three PhD students presented work at scientific conferences, including presentations at Evolution, American Society of Mammalogists, and the Comparative Nutrition Society and the Principal Investigator contributed to three international workshops aimed at training early career researchers to use DNA in studies of wildlife foraging behaviors. Support provided by this award also enabled us to maintain the UHURU experiment, which is a major international resource for long-term ecological research at Mpala Research Centre. The project also supported collaborative research involving two Masters students, three Postdoctoral Researchers, and numerous undergraduates at Brown University in addition to seven field-based researchers at Mpala Research Centre in Kenya.
